mainmatter.p: This is a placeholder tree for links.

The exponentials of sheaves coincide with those of presheaves. To see this, we assume X^YXYX^YXY is the exponential of sheaves and calculate \begin {aligned} \Gamma (U, X^Y) &= \hom _{ \mathsf { Psh } }( \mathop { \mkern {-2mu} \text {よ} \mkern {-2mu}} (U), X^Y) \\ &= \hom _{ \mathsf { Sh } }( \mathop { \mkern {-2mu} \text {よ} \mkern {-2mu}} (U)^{++}, X^Y) \\ &= \hom _{ \mathsf { Sh } }(Y \times \mathop { \mkern {-2mu} \text {よ} \mkern {-2mu}} (U)^{++}, X) \\ &= \hom _{ \mathsf { Sh } }(Y^{++} \times \mathop { \mkern {-2mu} \text {よ} \mkern {-2mu}} (U)^{++}, X) \\ &= \hom _{ \mathsf { Sh } }((Y \times \mathop { \mkern {-2mu} \text {よ} \mkern {-2mu}} (U))^{++}, X) \\ &= \hom _{ \mathsf { Psh } }(Y \times \mathop { \mkern {-2mu} \text {よ} \mkern {-2mu}} (U), X) \\ \end {aligned}Γ(U,XY)=hom⁡Psh(よ(U),XY)=hom⁡Sh(よ(U)++,XY)=hom⁡Sh(Y×よ(U)++,X)=hom⁡Sh(Y++×よ(U)++,X)=hom⁡Sh((Y×よ(U))++,X)=hom⁡Psh(Y×よ(U),X)\begin {aligned} \Gamma (U, X^Y) &= \hom _{ \mathsf { Psh } }( \mathop { \mkern {-2mu} \text {よ} \mkern {-2mu}} (U), X^Y) \\ &= \hom _{ \mathsf { Sh } }( \mathop { \mkern {-2mu} \text {よ} \mkern {-2mu}} (U)^{++}, X^Y) \\ &= \hom _{ \mathsf { Sh } }(Y \times \mathop { \mkern {-2mu} \text {よ} \mkern {-2mu}} (U)^{++}, X) \\ &= \hom _{ \mathsf { Sh } }(Y^{++} \times \mathop { \mkern {-2mu} \text {よ} \mkern {-2mu}} (U)^{++}, X) \\ &= \hom _{ \mathsf { Sh } }((Y \times \mathop { \mkern {-2mu} \text {よ} \mkern {-2mu}} (U))^{++}, X) \\ &= \hom _{ \mathsf { Psh } }(Y \times \mathop { \mkern {-2mu} \text {よ} \mkern {-2mu}} (U), X) \\ \end {aligned}Γ(U,XY)​=homPsh​(よ(U),XY)=homSh​(よ(U)++,XY)=homSh​(Y×よ(U)++,X)=homSh​(Y++×よ(U)++,X)=homSh​((Y×よ(U))++,X)=homPsh​(Y×よ(U),X)​ which is evidently \Gamma (U, X^Y)Γ(U,XY)\Gamma (U, X^Y)Γ(U,XY) but this time the exponential is taken in the category of presheaves. We used the fact that the plus construction preserves finite product. However, we still need to prove that this indeed forms a sheaf.

Expressing the sheaf condition using Lawvere–Tierney operators, we only need to show for dense subobjects F \hookrightarrow GF↪GF \hookrightarrow GF↪G that \hom (G, X^Y) \to \hom (F, X^Y)hom⁡(G,XY)→hom⁡(F,XY)\hom (G, X^Y) \to \hom (F, X^Y)hom(G,XY)→hom(F,XY) is a bijection. This is equivalent to \hom (Y \times G, X) \to \hom (Y \times F, X).hom⁡(Y×G,X)→hom⁡(Y×F,X).\hom (Y \times G, X) \to \hom (Y \times F, X).hom(Y×G,X)→hom(Y×F,X). Note that the subobject Y \times F \hookrightarrow Y \times GY×F↪Y×GY \times F \hookrightarrow Y \times GY×F↪Y×G corresponds to the characteristic function Y \times G \to G \to \OmegaY×G→G→ΩY \times G \to G \to \OmegaY×G→G→Ω. Hence the denseness of F \hookrightarrow GF↪GF \hookrightarrow GF↪G implies the denseness of Y \times F \hookrightarrow Y \times GY×F↪Y×GY \times F \hookrightarrow Y \times GY×F↪Y×G. Since XXXX is a sheaf, we conclude that X^YXYX^YXY is also a sheaf.

Given a mathematical object XXXX canonically associated with an effective chain complex C_ \bullet (X)C∙(X)C_ \bullet (X)C∙​(X) (e.g. the normalized chain complex of a simplicial set), it is said to be equipped with the structure of effective homology, if we have a strong homology equivalence C_ \bullet (X) \Leftarrow \mkern {-13mu} \Leftrightarrow \mkern {-13mu} \Rightarrow E_ \bulletC∙(X)⇐⇔⇒E∙C_ \bullet (X) \Leftarrow \mkern {-13mu} \Leftrightarrow \mkern {-13mu} \Rightarrow E_ \bulletC∙​(X)⇐⇔⇒E∙​, such that E_ \bulletE∙E_ \bulletE∙​ is effective of finite type.

The following data are equivalent: A chain reduction \rho : C \Rightarrow \mkern {-14mu} \Rightarrow Dρ:C⇒⇒D\rho : C \Rightarrow \mkern {-14mu} \Rightarrow Dρ:C⇒⇒D. A splitting C \cong D \oplus EC≅D⊕EC \cong D \oplus EC≅D⊕E, where EEEE is a split exact. A chain homotopy h : C \to Ch:C→Ch : C \to Ch:C→C satisfying h \circ h = 0h∘h=0h \circ h = 0h∘h=0 and h \circ d_C \circ h = hh∘dC∘h=hh \circ d_C \circ h = hh∘dC​∘h=h.

A chain reduction consists of maps C_k \mathrel { \smash { \xtofrom [g_k]{f_k}}} D_kCk⇄gkfkDkC_k \mathrel { \smash { \xtofrom [g_k]{f_k}}} D_kCk​fk​gk​​Dk​ such that f_k \circ g_k = \operatorname {id}fk∘gk=id⁡f_k \circ g_k = \operatorname {id}fk​∘gk​=id. Therefore C_ \bulletC∙C_ \bulletC∙​ splits as D_ \bullet \oplus E_ \bulletD∙⊕E∙D_ \bullet \oplus E_ \bulletD∙​⊕E∙​, and the boundary maps are preserved since f, gf,gf, gf,g are chain maps. We have a homotopy h_k : D_k \oplus E_k \to D_{k+1} \oplus E_{k+1}hk:Dk⊕Ek→Dk+1⊕Ek+1h_k : D_k \oplus E_k \to D_{k+1} \oplus E_{k+1}hk​:Dk​⊕Ek​→Dk+1​⊕Ek+1​, which we may write as a (2 \times 2)(2×2)(2 \times 2)(2×2)-matrix. f \circ h = 0f∘h=0f \circ h = 0f∘h=0 demands the first row to be zero, and h \circ g = 0h∘g=0h \circ g = 0h∘g=0 requires the first column to vanish. This leaves us with \begin {bmatrix} 0 & 0 \\ 0 & r_k \end {bmatrix}[000rk]\begin {bmatrix} 0 & 0 \\ 0 & r_k \end {bmatrix}[00​0rk​​] such that r_{k+1} \circ r_k = 0rk+1∘rk=0r_{k+1} \circ r_k = 0rk+1​∘rk​=0, since h \circ h = 0h∘h=0h \circ h = 0h∘h=0.

Substituting the requirement that hhhh is a homotopy \operatorname {id} \to g \circ fid⁡→g∘f\operatorname {id} \to g \circ fid→g∘f, we get the equation d_{k+1} \circ r_k + r_{k-1} \circ d_k = \operatorname {id} ,dk+1∘rk+rk−1∘dk=id⁡,d_{k+1} \circ r_k + r_{k-1} \circ d_k = \operatorname {id} ,dk+1​∘rk​+rk−1​∘dk​=id, where dddd is the boundary operator on E_ \bulletE∙E_ \bulletE∙​. In other words, rrrr is a null-homotopy of E_ \bulletE∙E_ \bulletE∙​, rendering it split exact. Conversely, given C \cong D \oplus EC≅D⊕EC \cong D \oplus EC≅D⊕E, we can reconstruct ffff and gggg as the projection and inclusion maps, with hhhh obtained out of rrrr in the manner depicted above.

On the other hand, given only the homotopy operator, we expect to have d \circ h + h \circ d = \operatorname {id} - g \circ fd∘h+h∘d=id⁡−g∘fd \circ h + h \circ d = \operatorname {id} - g \circ fd∘h+h∘d=id−g∘f. And since g \circ fg∘fg \circ fg∘f should be the projector of CCCC onto the subspace DDDD, \operatorname {id} - g \circ fid⁡−g∘f\operatorname {id} - g \circ fid−g∘f should be the projector onto EEEE. We are thus led to proving p = d \circ h + h \circ dp=d∘h+h∘dp = d \circ h + h \circ dp=d∘h+h∘d is indeed a projector. \begin {aligned} p_k \circ p_k &= (d_{k+1} \circ h_k + h_{k-1} \circ d_k) \circ (d_{k+1} \circ h_k + h_{k-1} \circ d_k) \\ &= d_{k+1} \circ \overbrace {h_k \circ d_{k+1} \circ h_k}^{h_k} + d_{k+1} \circ \overbrace {h_k \circ h_{k-1}}^{0} \circ d_k \\ & \qquad + h_{k-1} \circ \underbrace {d_k \circ d_{k+1}}_{0} \circ h_k + \underbrace {h_{k-1} \circ d_k \circ h_{k-1}}_{h_{k-1}} \circ d_k \\ &= d_{k+1} \circ h_k + h_{k-1} \circ d_k = p_k. \end {aligned}pk∘pk=(dk+1∘hk+hk−1∘dk)∘(dk+1∘hk+hk−1∘dk)=dk+1∘hk∘dk+1∘hk⏞hk+dk+1∘hk∘hk−1⏞0∘dk+hk−1∘dk∘dk+1⏟0∘hk+hk−1∘dk∘hk−1⏟hk−1∘dk=dk+1∘hk+hk−1∘dk=pk.\begin {aligned} p_k \circ p_k &= (d_{k+1} \circ h_k + h_{k-1} \circ d_k) \circ (d_{k+1} \circ h_k + h_{k-1} \circ d_k) \\ &= d_{k+1} \circ \overbrace {h_k \circ d_{k+1} \circ h_k}^{h_k} + d_{k+1} \circ \overbrace {h_k \circ h_{k-1}}^{0} \circ d_k \\ & \qquad + h_{k-1} \circ \underbrace {d_k \circ d_{k+1}}_{0} \circ h_k + \underbrace {h_{k-1} \circ d_k \circ h_{k-1}}_{h_{k-1}} \circ d_k \\ &= d_{k+1} \circ h_k + h_{k-1} \circ d_k = p_k. \end {aligned}pk​∘pk​​=(dk+1​∘hk​+hk−1​∘dk​)∘(dk+1​∘hk​+hk−1​∘dk​)=dk+1​∘hk​∘dk+1​∘hk​​hk​​+dk+1​∘hk​∘hk−1​​0​∘dk​+hk−1​∘0dk​∘dk+1​​​∘hk​+hk−1​hk−1​∘dk​∘hk−1​​​∘dk​=dk+1​∘hk​+hk−1​∘dk​=pk​.​ Therefore we conclude that p_kpkp_kpk​ splits C_k \cong D_k \oplus E_kCk≅Dk⊕EkC_k \cong D_k \oplus E_kCk​≅Dk​⊕Ek​. More over, p \circ d = d \circ h \circ d = d \circ pp∘d=d∘h∘d=d∘pp \circ d = d \circ h \circ d = d \circ pp∘d=d∘h∘d=d∘p, meaning pppp is a chain map, and therefore the splitting is compatible with the boundary operator. Since h \circ p = p \circ h = h \circ d \circ h = hh∘p=p∘h=h∘d∘h=hh \circ p = p \circ h = h \circ d \circ h = hh∘p=p∘h=h∘d∘h=h, the homotopy is also compatible with the splitting, so we can restrict it onto E_kEkE_kEk​ to get a homotopy from \operatorname {id} _Eid⁡E\operatorname {id} _EidE​ to 0000.

Finally, restricting hhhh onto D_kDkD_kDk​ we see that it must be zero, since h( \operatorname {id} - p) = h - h \circ d \circ h = 0h(id⁡−p)=h−h∘d∘h=0h( \operatorname {id} - p) = h - h \circ d \circ h = 0h(id−p)=h−h∘d∘h=0. This means that all the information of hhhh can be reconstructed from the splitting, and thus all three sets of data are equivalent.

Given an algebraic cellular complex, suppose we can encode the basis sets C_ \bulletC∙C_ \bulletC∙​ such that they have decidable equality, and the maps C_k \to \mathbb {Z}^{(C_{k-1})}Ck→Z(Ck−1)C_k \to \mathbb {Z}^{(C_{k-1})}Ck​→Z(Ck−1​) are computable, then we say the ACC is effective. Suppose further that C_ \bulletC∙C_ \bulletC∙​ are (computably) finite sets, then we say it is effective of finite type.

frontmatter.title: An additive functor is exact iff it preserves quasi-isomorphisms

mainmatter.p: Given an additive functor F : \mathcal { A } \to \mathcal { B }F:A→BF : \mathcal { A } \to \mathcal { B }F:A→B between abelian categories, it is exact iff it sends quasi-isomorphisms to quasi-isomorphisms.
Suppose an additive functor preserves quasi-isomorphisms. Since a chain complex is exact iff it is quasi-isomorphic to the zero complex, the functor must preserve exactness.

On the other hand, exact functors commute with homology functors. Therefore if f : C_ \bullet \to D_ \bulletf:C∙→D∙f : C_ \bullet \to D_ \bulletf:C∙​→D∙​ is a quasi-isomorphism, H_n (f)Hn(f)H_n (f)Hn​(f) are all isomorphisms. Therefore H_n (F(f)) = F(H_n(f))Hn(F(f))=F(Hn(f))H_n (F(f)) = F(H_n(f))Hn​(F(f))=F(Hn​(f)) is the functorial action on an isomorphism, which must also produce an isomorphism.

For a chain reduction C \Rightarrow \mkern {-14mu} \Rightarrow DC⇒⇒DC \Rightarrow \mkern {-14mu} \Rightarrow DC⇒⇒D, DDDD is embedded as a subcomplex of CCCC. It is cleanly separated, indicating that it is split. The other part of CCCC is split exact, and so its homology component is drawn as empty, with the components separated.

mainmatter.p: In an abelian category, given the middle two rows of the diagram

embedded-tex.embedded-tex-preamble: \usepackage{mlmodern, tikz, tikz-cd, quiver, mathtools, amssymb, stmaryrd, mathrsfs}
embedded-tex.embedded-tex-body: \begin {tikzcd} & { \ker f} & { \ker g} & { \ker h} \\ { \ker i} & \bullet & \bullet & \bullet & 0 \\ 0 & \bullet & \bullet & \bullet & { \operatorname {coker} j} \\ & { \operatorname {coker} f} & { \operatorname {coker} g} & { \operatorname {coker} h} \arrow ["f", from=2-2, to=3-2] \arrow ["g", from=2-3, to=3-3] \arrow ["h", from=2-4, to=3-4] \arrow [from=1-2, to=2-2] \arrow [from=1-3, to=2-3] \arrow [from=1-4, to=2-4] \arrow [blue, >->, out=90, in=180, from=2-1, to=1-2] \arrow [from=2-1, to=2-2] \arrow ["i", from=2-2, to=2-3] \arrow [from=2-3, to=2-4] \arrow [from=3-2, to=3-3] \arrow ["j", from=3-3, to=3-4] \arrow [from=3-4, to=3-5] \arrow [blue, ->>, out=0, in=-90, from=4-4, to=3-5] \arrow [from=3-2, to=4-2] \arrow [from=3-3, to=4-3] \arrow [from=3-4, to=4-4] \arrow [blue, from=1-2, to=1-3] \arrow [blue, from=1-3, to=1-4] \arrow [blue, from=4-2, to=4-3] \arrow [blue, from=4-3, to=4-4] \arrow [blue, dashed, out=0, in=180, from=1-4, to=4-2] \arrow [from=2-4, to=2-5] \arrow [from=3-1, to=3-2] \end {tikzcd}

mainmatter.p: such that the rows are exact, we can take the kernels and cokernels, which forms a long exact sequence of blue arrows, 0 \to \ker i \to \ker f \to \ker g \to \ker h \xrightarrow { \partial } \operatorname {coker} f \to \operatorname {coker} g \to \operatorname {coker} h \to \operatorname {coker} j \to 00→ker⁡i→ker⁡f→ker⁡g→ker⁡h→∂coker⁡f→coker⁡g→coker⁡h→coker⁡j→00 \to \ker i \to \ker f \to \ker g \to \ker h \xrightarrow { \partial } \operatorname {coker} f \to \operatorname {coker} g \to \operatorname {coker} h \to \operatorname {coker} j \to 00→keri→kerf→kerg→kerh∂​cokerf→cokerg→cokerh→cokerj→0. In particular, if iiii is monic and jjjj is epic, this leads to a six-term exact sequence.
There are multiple ways to prove this claim. We can first prove it in categories of modules, and use the Freyd–Mitchell embedding. We can also use pseudo-elements to perform diagram chases.

frontmatter.title: Using the Freyd–Mitchell embedding to prove theorems

mainmatter.p: We use the snake lemma as an example to demonstrate how the embedding theorem works in practice. The main technique is to avoid dealing with large categories.

Suppose we have already proved the theorem in module categories. Given a snake lemma diagram in an arbitrary (locally small) abelian category \mathcal { C }C\mathcal { C }C, we take the smallest full subcategory closed under finite limits and colimits. This results in a small category \mathcal { D }D\mathcal { D }D, which we can embed in a module category R \text {-} \mathsf { Mod }R-ModR \text {-} \mathsf { Mod }R-Mod.

Now, the snake lemma in module categories implies that we have the required maps that forms an exact sequence. Since \mathcal { D }D\mathcal { D }D is a full abelian subcategory of R \text {-} \mathsf { Mod }R-ModR \text {-} \mathsf { Mod }R-Mod, these morphisms are contained in \mathcal { D }D\mathcal { D }D, and the sequence is still exact. And since \mathcal { D }D\mathcal { D }D is a full abelian subcategory of \mathcal { C }C\mathcal { C }C, the sequence is again exact in \mathcal { C }C\mathcal { C }C.

frontmatter.title: Being an additive category is a property

mainmatter.p: Given a category, if it can be endowed with an \mathsf { Ab }Ab\mathsf { Ab }Ab-enrichment that makes it an additive category, then it only has one possible enrichment. In particular, there is at most one way to turn a category into an additive category.
Notice that having finite products and coproducts is a property, and the canonical morphism between them being an isomorphism is also a property. These do not mention the enrichment structure.

With these properties satisfied, the addition structure on the \homhom⁡\homhom-sets are fixed. We claim that the additive neutral element is given by the composition X \to 0 \to Y,X→0→Y,X \to 0 \to Y,X→0→Y, and given two parallel morphisms f, g : X \to Yf,g:X→Yf, g : X \to Yf,g:X→Y, the following composition X \xrightarrow { \Delta } X \oplus X \xrightarrow {f \oplus g} Y \oplus Y \xrightarrow { \nabla } Y.X→ΔX⊕X→f⊕gY⊕Y→∇Y.X \xrightarrow { \Delta } X \oplus X \xrightarrow {f \oplus g} Y \oplus Y \xrightarrow { \nabla } Y.XΔ​X⊕Xf⊕g​Y⊕Y∇​Y. is equal to the addition f + gf+gf + gf+g. For disambiguation, we temporarily denote these constructions as 0'0′0'0′ and f +' gf+′gf +' gf+′g. By interpreting \oplus⊕\oplus⊕ as a product or a coproduct at appropriate times, it is easy to see that 0'0′0'0′ is indeed the neutral element for +'+′+'+′.

Recall that arrows X \oplus X \to Y \oplus YX⊕X→Y⊕YX \oplus X \to Y \oplus YX⊕X→Y⊕Y is given by a 2 \times 22×22 \times 22×2 matrix, and this correspondence is an abelian group isomorphism by general enriched category theory. f \oplus gf⊕gf \oplus gf⊕g comes from a diagonal matrix with f, gf,gf, gf,g as entries, so this operation is linear, which entails +'+′+'+′ is also linear. By the Eckmann–Hilton argument, the two addition operations must coincide.
This is where I sort through my forest. Unwritten links are recorded here. Here is a list of all the trees:
